title: Midgut Volvulus due to Malrotation
diagnosis_topic: Twisting of the midgut around the superior mesenteric artery causing obstruction and ischemia
setup_script: A 2-week-old infant presents with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Parents report the baby becoming increasingly lethargic.

dynamic_flow.reply: HR 170 bpm, RR 50/min, BP 70/40 mmHg, Temp 36.5 C.
Distended, tender abdomen with visible peristalsis; bilious gastric aspirate present via NG tube.
Metabolic acidosis (pH 7.25), elevated lactate, electrolyte imbalances due to dehydration.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders upper GI contrast study
dynamic_flow.reply: Shows corkscrew appearance of duodenum with abnormal location of ligament of Treitz, consistent with malrotation with volvulus.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates resuscitation with IV fluids and antibiotics

dynamic_flow.reply: Emergent laparotomy performed; Ladd's bands divided, counterclockwise detorsion, broadening of mesenteric base and appendectomy.
Rapid progression to bowel necrosis, sepsis and death.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about malrotation presentation
dynamic_flow.reply: Bilious vomiting in neonates should be considered volvulus until proven otherwise.
Monitor for short bowel syndrome if resection needed; recurrent volvulus is rare.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident evaluates for associated anomalies
dynamic_flow.reply: Screen for heterotaxy and cardiac anomalies.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident explains Ladd's procedure steps
dynamic_flow.reply: Divide Ladd's bands, widen mesenteric pedicle and place small intestine on right, colon on left.
Educate on signs of bowel obstruction and ensure follow-up with pediatric surgery.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of bilious vomiting as surgical emergency suggesting malrotation
Use of upper GI contrast study to diagnose volvulus
Urgent surgical correction via Ladd's procedure
Avoidance of delays that lead to bowel necrosis
